race.name: Fairfield Harvest Rush
race.tagline: Fairfield Harvest Rush. 55 miles of gravel through Fairfield.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Iowa countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Iowa event. Rolling terrain with good access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Fairfield Harvest Rush is a local event in Iowa—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Iowa countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Iowa gravel race. Worth it for Iowa/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Iowa—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Iowa races: Trans Iowa, Spotted Horse Ultra.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Fairfield has limited lodging options. Book ahead.
logistics.food: Fairfield has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.

course_description.ridewithgps_name: Dry 100KM Fairfield Harvest Rush  2024 - Taylor Swift's Fists

non_negotiables.why: Iowa rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Packet pickup Friday 6-8PM and Saturday morning check-in at 6:30AM shows reasonable scheduling. Maasdam Barns provides a real venue, not some parking lot start. Routes posted Wednesday before the race via email gives you time to study, though the lack of specific aid station details leaves questions.

length.explanation: The 50K option at ~35 miles is barely a gravel workout. Even the 100K at ~65 miles won't challenge anyone's endurance limits. When your shorter option needs a rain route backup, you're not exactly pushing boundaries.

technicality.explanation: Jefferson County has "more dirt roads than any neighboring county" according to race organizers, but "difficult terrain with longer, steeper hills" doesn't translate to technical challenge. This is still Iowa B-roads - more grinding than handling skills required.

elevation.explanation: The "difficult terrain with longer, steeper hills" description suggests more bite than typical Iowa rolling country. Jefferson County's B-roads deliver 1500-3000 feet of climbing that'll work your legs without breaking your spirit.

climate.explanation: October 4th in Iowa is prime riding weather - cool mornings, crisp afternoons, minimal heat stress. They prep rain routes because weather gets unpredictable, but that's smart planning. Fall in the Midwest beats summer anywhere for gravel grinding.

altitude.explanation: Fairfield sits around 700-800 feet above sea level. Your biggest altitude challenge is getting out of bed at the hotel. If elevation affects your performance here, you've got bigger problems than race selection.

adventure.explanation: Jefferson County's "backroads with lots of gravel to grind on" offer access to more B-roads than any Iowa race. The harvest season timing adds pastoral charm, but let's not confuse bucolic countryside with true adventure.

prestige.explanation: Gabe Hobbie took second in the 100K and landed on the Iowa Gravel Series Podium Podcast, which shows some competitive depth. Still described as "friendly to both new and experienced racers" - welcoming doesn't equal prestigious.

race_quality.explanation: Gabe Hobbie's podium finish and podcast appearance suggests competitive racing happens here. Well-marked routes and SAG support cover the basics, though "friendly to both new and experienced racers" signals accessible over challenging.

experience.explanation: The emphasis on being a race "you can invite your family or buddy that's new to gravel grinding" speaks to welcoming atmosphere over memorable challenge. Solid organization and community support create pleasant day out rather than epic tale.

community.explanation: Gabe Hobbie's Iowa Gravel Series Podium Podcast appearance shows riders get recognized beyond the finish line. The "friendly to both new and experienced racers" ethos with emphasis on inviting newcomers demonstrates inclusive community spirit.

field_depth.explanation: Over 150 racers sounds decent until you realize that's across three different courses. No mention of notable riders, pro categories, or competitive depth. When the race description focuses on being 'friendly to new racers,' the sharks aren't circling these waters.

value.explanation: $40 grassroots entry with chip timing, aid stations, SAG support, and pro photography is honest pricing. The $399 Iowa Gravel Series pass covering all seven races sweetens the deal if you're doing the circuit.

expenses.explanation: Fairfield, Iowa won't bankrupt you on lodging or dining. The Fishback and Stephenson Cider House venue suggests easy access without big city markup. Day-of registration accepts cash or card, keeping logistics simple.
